<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIL ORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Computer assisted mail-order <br><br> As soon as the home computers could communicate easily through modem with large computer sites, the major mail-order companies had the idea to sell products to the computers users. This  concept was facilitated in France by the free distribution of the 'Minitel' Videotex terminal that was gradually integrated into home computers. The success gained by this system in France did not have any equal in the rest of the world.  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SCARY...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Can you believe it?! She is learning how to play flute (mini flute?) with her TO7... The father seems to be a kind of lunatic...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption.  <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
